texts.definition: Postures and gestures that convey gameplay information that can be performed while roleplaying.
markups: <style="Definition">Postures and gestures that convey gameplay information that can be performed while roleplaying.</style>

Players of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">Live Action Roleplaying Games</link></style> may need to communicate with each other about issues related to the game state. <style="CurrentLink">Meta-Postures</style> is a way of being able to do this while continuing to roleplay by letting certain postures or gestures have pre-agreed meanings.

<style="CurrentLink">Meta-Postures</style> are used in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">Live Action Roleplaying Games</link></style>. One example of such a posture is that of holding your arms crossed over your chest which in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mind's%20Eye%20Theatre">Mind's Eye Theatre</link></style> rules show that the vampire you are playing is obfuscated. Another example can be found in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Avatar%20System">Avatar System</link></style> where players make a hand symbol to indicate that a discussion is taking place outside the game.

The design of <style="CurrentLink">Meta-Postures</style> consist of selecting which information should be possible to exchange through <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-communication">Non-Diegetic Communication</link></style> and selecting gestures or postures. The latter requires consideration regarding how easy they are to learn, how distinct they are from each other, how well they fit in with <style="Link"><link="physical-enactment">Physical Enactment</link></style> players are likely to be doing, and how noticeable they are (which is a balance between being easy to detect and breaking <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>).

Being a pattern of how players can signal each other through postures and gestures, <style="CurrentLink">Meta-Postures</style> is a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Information%20Patterns">Information Pattern</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Meta-Postures</style> is one subgroup to <style="Link"><link="meta-techniques">Meta-Techniques</link></style>. Another, <style="Link"><link="substitute-actions">Substitute Actions</link></style>, work against <style="CurrentLink">Meta-Postures</style> regarding how to solve the same design problems. The pattern limits <style="Link"><link="physical-enactment">Physical Enactment</link></style> somewhat since players may not have a full range of postures and gestures available while presenting a <style="CurrentLink">Meta-Posture</style>.

While <style="CurrentLink">Meta-Postures</style> can support <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> by making some <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-communication">Non-Diegetic Communication</link></style> more discrete, it may also increase the amount of <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-communication">Non-Diegetic Communication</link></style> which can counteract its purpose.
